items.q: What is the only mammal capable of sustained true flight?
items.explanation: While 'flying' squirrels can glide long distances, only bats have true wings that allow for powered flight.
The sun is a medium-sized star physically located at the center of our solar system.

items.q: A mushroom is a type of plant.
items.explanation: A mushroom is a part of a fungus, which belongs to its own separate biological kingdom distinct from plants.

items.a: A thermometer measures temperature, or how hot or cold something is.
items.explanation: It's essential for monitoring the weather or checking for fevers.

items.q: Describe what camouflage means in nature.
items.a: Camouflage is when an animal's coloration or pattern allows it to blend into its environment, helping it hide from predators or sneak up on prey.
items.explanation: Chameleons and some octopuses can actively change their color to match their surroundings.

items.q: Why do some trees lose their leaves in the autumn?
items.a: These deciduous trees drop their leaves to conserve water and energy during the cold winter months when there is less sunlight and frozen ground.
items.explanation: This natural cycle helps the tree survive until spring.

items.a: An animal or person that eats both plants and meat.
items.explanation: Humans, bears, and pigs are classic examples of omnivores.

items.q: Which ocean is the largest on Earth?
items.explanation: It covers more than 30% of the Earth's surface and is larger than all of Earth's landmass combined.

items.q: What do we call the young offspring of a frog?
items.explanation: Tadpoles live entirely in water, breathe through gills, and have tails before they undergo metamorphosis.

items.q: Name the process by which liquid water becomes vapor in the atmosphere.
items.explanation: Heat from the sun causes water from oceans, lakes, and soils to turn into gas and rise upward.
